div.h2: WUSD SCHOOLS AND PLAYGROUNDS ARE CLOSED

div.p:
WUSD SCHOOLS, including all PLAYGROUNDS, are officially CLOSED for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year, in response to the latest executive "Safer at Home" order issued by Governor Tony Evers on April 16th, 2020.
Please click here for the latest family information from Superintendent Cassandra Schug and visit our COVID-19 webpage for additional information and resources.
Meal pick up information may be found here: English & Spanish.
WUSD Families - please complete this brief survey so we can better serve your student(s) during this time: English Survey Spanish Survey.
If you need immediate assistance, please email your building administrator or call (920)262-1460.
We will get through this together - #WatertownWay!

span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus Updates & Virtual Learning

h2.span: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

span.span: APRIL 16TH UPDATE: GOVERNOR EXTENDS "SAFER AT HOME" ORDER
ALL WUSD SCHOOLS AND PLAYGROUNDS ARE CLOSED FOR THE REMAINDER OF THE 2019-20 SCHOOL YEAR

td.p: On April 16th, 2020, Governor Evers extended the "Safer at Home" order that officially closes all K-12 Wisconsin schools and playgrounds, both public and private, for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain the spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin. WUSD households with students in grades 3-12 who are still in need of a technology device for virtual and distance learning, please call (920)262-1420 or follow the email links below depending on your need. As we know more, we will be communicating with our students, staff and families.

span.a: Need a Hotspot (back ordered until late April)

p.br: “Closing our schools is not a decision I made lightly, but keeping our kids, our educators, our families, and our communities safe is a top priority as we continue our work to respond to and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin,” Evers said. “Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care. We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”

The Watertown Unified School District will be closed for students for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year or until the WUSD receives a new or lifted order from Governor Evers and/or further recommendations from the CDC, DPI and the Wisconsin Department of Health. All after-school activities and athletics, including practices, are also canceled for the remainder of the order.

Please know that we understand that these are unique times, and that each of you may have unique circumstances in your home and/or family. If your family circumstances are such that you and/or your son/daughter has a medical condition and/or underlying health condition that is of concern, please reach out to your building principal, the WUSD nurse, or the Watertown Health Department to communicate any unique circumstances so we can take any necessary precautions.

br.br: The WUSD is continuing to instruct our students through distance and online learning environments. Please continue to work with your teachers and building administrator as we navigate through this process. We are here to support you.

td.p: The WUSD will be offering free breakfast and lunch for all children in our community 18 years of age and under during our school closure. Meal pick-ups will be available Monday through Friday for the remainder of the 2019-20 school year.

ul.li: Kwik Trip (Hwy 19 location near WHS) - 10:00 a.m. to 11:30 a.m.
Educational Service Center (ESC - 111 Dodge Street) - 10:30 a.m. to 12:00 p.m.
Schurz Elementary School (1508 Neenah Street) - 11:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.
Area Dental Clinic Parking Lot (Boughton Street) - 11:30 a.m. to 1:00 p.m.

p.strong: PLEASE COMPLETE THIS BRIEF SURVEY TO ASSIST THE WUSD IN SERVING OUR STUDENTS BOTH ACADEMICALLY AND NUTRITIONALLY:

br.br: As always, the safety of our students, staff, and families remains our top priority. We will act with an abundance of caution to protect everyone’s health and well-being. Thank you again for your cooperation and understanding. The COVID-19 situation is constantly evolving and changing. We understand there is uncertainty involved in this situation and we will continue to keep you as informed as possible.

p.br: If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact our District Nurse, Lynn Gilbert at 920-262-1460 extension 3219, the Watertown Health Department at 920-262-8090, or by reaching out directly to me at 920-262-1460 ext. 3229.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Schug
Superintendent of Schools
#WatertownWay

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:

p.br: Please contact your school to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease.

br.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in the Watertown Unified School District.

p.br: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Jefferson and Dodge County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin - in Fond Du Lac, Pierce, Waukesha, and Dane counties. Another 37 WI residents are returning from a cruise where they may have been exposed and will be self-quarantined for 14 days. Nationally, there have been approximately 1,000 confirmed cases and 30 deaths (none in Wisconsin).

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: WUSD has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.

div.br: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.

td.p: This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic, the President and Governor declaring it a public health emergency and the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13 on all travel from Europe to the U.S.

div.br: The state of Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS) is asking schools and organizations to:

ul.li: Avoid traveling to areas in the US with sustained community transmission of COVID-19 (currently Washington, New York, and California). See map of US sustained community transmission of COVID-19.
Self-quarantine for 14 days upon return for anyone who travels to any U.S. states with confirmed community spread of COVID-19.

p.br: Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country with a Level 3 travel health notice, please contact your school before returning to school. The CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days. Read more about travel on the CDC's website.
We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students’ safety first.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact our District Nurse, Lynn Gilbert at 920-262-1460 extension 3219, the Watertown Health Department at 920-262-8090, or Superintendent Cassandra Schug at 920-262-1460 ext. 3229.
